children.name: like
children.definition: /laɪk/  to think that something is nice, attractive, enjoyable etc:
examples: ▪ i like your dress - it’s a beautiful colour.
▪ do you like spaghetti?
like something about something
▪ what did you like about the movie?
like doing something/like to do something
▪ i think roy likes living alone.
▪ i like to see the children enjoying themselves.

children.name: be fond of sb/ st
children.definition: be fond of/biː ˈfɒnd ɒvǁ-ˈfɑːnd/  especially british to like something, especially something that you have liked for alongtime:
examples: ▪ connie had always been fond of animals.
▪ he had always been fond of drinking at lunchtime, perhaps too fond.

children.name: be into
children.definition: /biː ˈintuː/ spokento like doing a particular activity or be interested in a particular subject:
examples: ▪ i know she’s really into sports, so i thought i’d ask her to come skiing with us.
▪ a lot of his relatives are into very weird new age stuff.

children.name: be keen on
children.definition: /biː ˈkiːn ɒn/  especially british to like or be very interested in an activity or idea:
examples: ▪ i know he’s keen on opera. let’s take him to see "la traviata'.
▪ i’m quite keen on the idea of having a fancy dress party.

children.name: appeal to
children.definition: /əˈpiːl tuː/  if something appeals to you, you like it because it involves things that interest you or ideas that you agree with:
examples: ▪ i’m sure this delightful book will appeal to children of all ages.
▪ does either suggestion appeal to you?

children.name: go down well
children.definition: also go over well american /ˌgəʊ daʊn ˈwel, ˌgəʊ əʊvəʳ ˈwel/  if something you do, or a book, film, performance etc goes down well with a group of people, they like it:
examples: ▪ her style of comedy is very british, but it goes down well in the states too.
go down well with
▪ at the present time, military action would not go over well with the international community

children.name: be to your liking
children.definition: /biː tə jɔːʳ ˈlaɪkɪŋ/  formal if something is to your liking it has the qualities that you like, or it is made in the way that you like:
examples: ▪ was the meal to your liking, madam?
▪ the surrounding countryside was very much to our liking.

children.name: sb who likes st very much
lover
children.definition: /ˈlʌvəʳ/  someone who likes a particular activity very much:
examples: music/car/wine/animal etc lover
▪ we are a nation of animal lovers.
▪ every jazz lover dreams of visiting new orleans.
lover of
▪ lovers of night life won’t be able to resist the many nightclubs in the area.

children.name: fan a2
children.definition: fan/fæn/  someone who likes a particular sport, team, orfamousentertainer very much:
examples: ▪ thousands of fans came to hear oasis play.
▪ a football fan
fan of
▪ fans of sylvester stallone will enjoy this movie.
fannoun[ c ]person người hâm mộ;người say mê
someone who admires and supports a person, sport, sports team, etc
_more than 15, 000liverpoolfans attended saturday's game.
_he's a big fanofcountry music.
_i'm pleased to meet you – i'm a great fanofyour work.

children.name: enthusiast
children.definition: /ɪnˈθjuːziæstǁ-ˈθuː-/  someone who likes a subject, activity, performer etc very much, is very interested in them and knows a lot about them:
examples: ▪ enthusiasts are willing to pay up to $12,000 for an original copy of the book.
football/film/jazz etc enthusiast
▪ golf enthusiasts will be able to see the tournament live on tv.
▪ the exhibition will be of interest to classic car owners and other motoring enthusiasts.

children.name: freak
children.definition: /friːk/  informal someone who is extremely interested in a particular activity, especially when other people think they are a little strange for liking it so much:
examples: health/tv/sports etc freak
▪ raw vegetables and nuts have always been a favourite with health-food freaks.
▪ one beatle’s freak is reported to have paid $18,000 for paul mccartney’s birth certificate.

children.name: junkie/addict
children.definition: /ˈdʒʌŋki, ˈædɪkt/  informal someone who does, eats, watches etc something a lot because they enjoy it so much that they cannot stop doing it - use this especially when you do not think someone should be spending so much time doing or being involved in a particular thing:
examples: tv/news/fast food etc junkie
▪ if you’re a shopping junkie, then this is the channel for you!
▪ you’d have to be a real political junkie to remember that tsongas won the new hampshire primary in 1992.
tv/news/fast food etc addict
▪ my sons and my husband are all football addicts.

children.name: devotee
children.definition: /ˌdevəˈtiː/  formal someone who likes something such as art or literature very much and spends a lot of their time and money on it:
examples: ▪ he’s a devotee of old hollywood movies.
▪ urquhart, a rich devotee of the arts, made generous donations to the museum.

children.name: be crazy about st
children.definition: be crazy aboutalsobe mad about somethingbritish /biː ˈkreɪzi əbaʊt, biː ˈmæd əbaʊt/ informalto be extremely interested in an activity and spend a lot of time doing it or watching it:
examples: ▪ jonah’s crazy about basketball.
▪ she’s always been mad about horses.

children.name: love/adore
children.definition: /lʌv, əˈdɔːʳ/  especially spoken to like something very much. adore is stronger but less common than love:
examples: ▪ we had a great time at disneyland. the kids loved it.
▪ i adore chocolate -- i could live on it.
love/adore doing something
▪ the older men loved hearing about russ’s success on the football field.
▪ jessie adored being the centre of attention.

children.name: be attached to
children.definition: /biː əˈtætʃt tuː/  to like something very much, especially something that you own or use, so that you would be upset if you lost it:
examples: ▪ mom gets very attached to her pets.
▪ casey had become quite attached to the comforts of his london home.

children.name: have a passion for
children.definition: /ˌhæv ə ˈpæʃən fɔːʳ/  to like an activity very much, because it gives you a lot of pleasure or excitement:
examples: ▪ from a very early age he had a passion for fast cars.
▪ to be a great performer, you have to work very hard and have a passion for the music you play.

children.name: be addicted to
children.definition: /bi əˈdɪktd tuː/  to enjoy doing something so much that you do it, watch it etc as often as you can and feel that you cannot stop doing it:
examples: ▪ my son’s addicted to computer games - he hardly ever comes out of his room.
be addicted
▪ i started watching the show out of curiosity, but now i’m addicted!

children.name: to like st that could be bad for you
can’t resist
children.definition: /ˌkɑːnt rɪˈzɪstǁˌkænt-/  to like something so much that you cannot refuse it when it is offered to you:
examples: ▪ my mother could never resist expensive perfumes.
can’t resist doing something
▪ i couldn’t resist stopping by the bakery on the way home.

children.name: have a weakness for
children.definition: /ˌhæv ə ˈwiːkns fɔːʳ/  informal to like a particular kind of food, drink, or activity, even though you know it is not good for you or that other people might not approve of it:
examples: ▪ too many of the men in our family have a weakness for alcohol.
▪ i have to admit i have a weakness for daytime soap operas.

children.name: be partial to
children.definition: /biː ˈpɑːʳʃəl tuː/  to like something such as a particular food or drink, especially when you eat or drink it more than you should:
examples: ▪ he was particularly partial to my mother’s home-made wine.

children.name: not be averse to
children.definition: /nɒt biː əˈvɜːʳs tuː/  to like something or like doing something, especially something that could be bad or dangerous. this is often used humorously about something that is not really very bad:
examples: ▪ she’s not averse to the occasional glass of wine.
not be averse to doing something
▪ the company is highly competitive and not averse to taking risks.

children.name: get to like
children.definition: /ˌget tə ˈlaɪk/  to begin to like something, especially something that you did not like at first:
examples: ▪ the more the two women talked, the more they got to like each other.
▪ i don’t think i could ever get to like hip-hop.

children.name: grow on
children.definition: /ˈgrəʊ ɒn/  if something grows on you, you gradually start to like it after a period of time:
examples: ▪ i didn’t like his accent much at first, but it kind of grows on you.
▪ ‘the furniture in this place is a little weird.’ ‘yeah, but it grows on you after a while.’

children.name: develop/acquire/get a taste for
children.definition: also develop a liking for something /dɪˌveləp, əˌkwaɪər, ˌget ə ˈteɪst fəʳ, dɪˌveləp ə ˈlaɪkɪŋ fəʳ something/  to begin to like something that you did not like or had not experienced before:
examples: ▪ while bev was married, she acquired a taste for luxurious living.
▪ when her family moved to hollywood, she developed a liking for movie magazines and film culture.
▪ sam soon got a taste for thai green curry and sticky rice.

children.name: be an acquired taste
children.definition: /biː ən əˌkwaɪəʳd ˈteɪst/  if something is an acquired taste, people tend not to like when they first try it, but begin to like it when they have tried it a few more times:
examples: ▪ dark beers and ales are an acquired taste, but there’s nothing better on a cold winter night.
▪ like most modern jazz players, his music’s a bit of an acquired taste.

children.name: likes and dislikes
children.definition: /ˌlaɪks ənd ˈdɪslaɪks/  all the things you like and do not like:
examples: ▪ she never lets her personal likes and dislikes affect the way she treats people.
▪ employees were asked about their likes and dislikes, and also about how they felt about their working conditions.

children.name: sb’s passion/sb’s love /
children.definition: somebody’s passion/somebody’s love/ somebodyˈs ˈpæʃən, somebodyˈs ˈlʌv/  something that you are deeply interested in and which you like so much that you are always excited about it:
examples: ▪ donna’s latest passion is cooking and eating mexican food.
somebody’s great/first love
▪ my father’s great love was fishing.

children.name: be fond of sb
children.definition: be fond of/biː ˈfɒnd ɒvǁ-ˈfɑːnd-/  to like someone very much, especially when you haveknownthem for alongtime:
examples: ▪ you’re very fond of tyler, aren’t you?
▪ over the years, the old man grew very fond of his nurse.

children.name: like
children.definition: /laɪk/  to think someone has good qualities so that you feel friendly towards them:
examples: ▪ i’ve always liked sally - she’s a lot of fun.
▪ everybody liked mr. schofield, but he wasn’t a very good teacher.
▪ i never really liked her - she was always a bit stuck-up and condescending.

children.name: be attached to
children.definition: /biː əˈtætʃt tuː/  to like someone that you have known for a long time, so that you would be upset if they left you:
examples: ▪ we’ve grown quite attached to you, annie, and we’ll be very sorry to see you leave.
▪ nurses can easily get too attached to their patients.

children.name: have a soft spot for
children.definition: /hæv ə ˌsɒft ˈspɒt fɔːʳǁ-ˌsɔːft ˈspɑːt-/  informal to like one person in particular more than the other people in a group:
examples: ▪ she’s always had a soft spot for her youngest grandson.
▪ i’ve had a soft spot for janet ever since she took my side in the argument i had with jimmy.

children.name: see st in
children.definition: see something in/ˈsiː something ɪn/  to like someone because of a particular quality that they have, especially when other people do not notice that quality in them:
examples: ▪ tom’s so innocent. he only sees the good in everyone he meets.
▪ i can’t figure out what doug sees in her.

children.name: a man/woman after your own heart
children.definition: /ə ˌmæn, ˌwʊmən ɑːftəʳ jɔːr ˌəʊn ˈhɑːʳtǁ-æf-/  spoken someone that you like because they have the same attitudes that you have, or like the same things that you like:
examples: ▪ i like the way she runs her business - a woman after my own heart.

children.name: hit it off
children.definition: /ˌhɪt ɪt ˈɒf/  if two people hit it off, they like each other, especially as soon as they meet:
examples: ▪ art howe asked him to come for an interview for the coaching job, and the two men hit it off immediately.
▪ those two didn’t really hit it off at first, did they?
hit it off with
▪ you can’t expect to hit it off with everyone you meet.

children.name: get/grow/come to like
children.definition: /ˌget,ˌgrəʊ, ˌkʌm tə ˈlaɪk/  to begin to like someone, especially someone that you did not like at first:
examples: ▪ at first i thought she was a bit weird, but now i’m getting to like her.
▪ over the years, we grew to like each other, despite our differences.
▪ i’ve gradually come to like larry and his eccentric habits.

children.name: warm to
children.definition: /ˈwɔːʳm tuː/  to begin to like someone and feel friendly towards them:
examples: ▪ her heart warmed to amos. he was obviously a man who loved animals.
▪ she was very nervous about introducing james to her children, but they warmed to him immediately.

children.name: take to/take a liking to
children.definition: /ˈteɪk tuː, ˌteɪk ə ˈlaɪkɪŋ tuː/  to begin to like someone, especially when you have only known them for a very short time:
examples: ▪ i introduced anders to my brother and they took to each other immediately.
▪ when nicky takes to someone the way he’s taken to you, he’s your friend for life.
▪ they only met yesterday, but i can tell jim’s taken a great liking to the girl.

children.name: endear yourself to
children.definition: /ɪnˈdɪəʳ jɔːʳself tu:/  to make someone like you by behaving in a way that pleases them:
examples: ▪ ‘can i help you mrs killigarew’ he said, hoping to endear himself to her by remembering her name.
▪ she was witty and charming and quickly managed to endear herself to her future mother-in-law.

children.name: get on the right side of sb
children.definition: get on the right side of somebodybritish informal also get on somebody’s good side american informal /ˌget ɒn ðə ˌraɪt ˈsaɪd əv somebody, ˌget ɒn somebodyˈs ˌgʊd ˈsaɪd/  to do nice things for someone and avoid making them angry, in order to be sure they like you:
examples: ▪ he’s only sent me flowers because he’s trying to get on the right side of me.
▪ chris doesn’t care what he has to say to get on miller’s good side.

children.name: win the hearts of
children.definition: /ˌwɪn ðə ˈhɑːʳts ɒv/  to make a lot of people like you very much, especially by doing something that they admire or approve of:
examples: ▪ with the words, ‘ich bin ein berliner,’ j.f. kennedy won the hearts of millions of germans.
▪ the slight, nervous-looking young gymnast won the hearts of a whole nation.
